sect2.title: Environment
sect2.para: Lets you specify/view environment variables. Environment variables can be used in headers, footers and Javadoc templates to form variable expressions that will be resolved during printing. I call this process variable interpolation.
Environment variables are simple key/value pairs. Valid keys take the form ([a-zA-Z_][a-zA-Z0-9_.])+ and are case-sensitive. Values can be freely choosen.

varlistentry.listitem: project = Jalopy Java Source Code Formatter

sect3.title: User environment variables
sect3.para: Lets you specify you're user specific environment variables. Use the Add... and Remove buttons to add or remove items to and from the list.

sect3.title: System environment variables
sect3.para: All system environment variables are automatically available as well but cannot be changed from within Jalopy.

sect3.title: Local environment variables
sect3.para: Additionaly, Jalopy provides some local variables that are automatically set depending on the execution context.
The current list of valid local variables reads as follows:

row.entry: The absolute path of the currently processed Java file (e.g. /usr/projects/test/MyFile.java)
The name of the currently processed Java file (e.g. MyFile.java)
A string represention of the file format that will be used to write a file (e.g. UNIX or DOS)
The package name of the currently processed Java file (e.g. com.foo.mypackage)
The name of the currently active code convention (as specified in the settings)
The current indentation setting (as specified in the settings)
Only applies to Javadoc templates: Holds the type name of the class for a constructor.
Only applies to Javadoc templates: Holds the type name of a parameter.
Only applies to Javadoc templates: Holds the type name of a throws clause.

sect3.title: Usage
sect3.para: Once defined, variables can then be enclosed with the dollar sign to form variable expressions. Variable expressions thus take the form $([a-zA-Z_][a-zA-Z0-9_.]+)$.
During printing these expressions will be interpolated and the value of the variable inserted into the output file.
